O'Driscoll:
  Hello everyone and welcome! My name is Michael O'Driscoll, and I'm a professor

  of English at the University of Alberta in Edmonton, Canada and a governing

O'Driscoll:
  board member of the SpokenWeb research network. I'd like to begin

O'Driscoll:
  by acknowledging the indigenous peoples of all the lands that we are on today.

O'Driscoll:
  the importance of the land that we each call home. We do this to

  reaffirm our commitment and responsibility in improving relationships between

O'Driscoll:
  nations and to improving our own understanding of local indigenous peoples

O'Driscoll:
  and their cultures. From coast to coast to coast we

  acknowledge the ancestral and unceded territory of all Inuit,

O'Driscoll:
  Métis, and First Nations that call this home. The

O'Driscoll:
  University of Alberta is located on Treaty 6 territory

O'Driscoll:
  and the Métis Nation Homeland. I invite each of you to consider

O'Driscoll:
  the traditional lands on which you might be located and take a moment to

O'Driscoll:
  consider the responsibilities that follow from that. The

O'Driscoll:
  SSHRC-funded SpokenWeb partnership brings together literary scholars

O'Driscoll:
  and digital humanists, librarians and archivists, media historians,

O'Driscoll:
  sound artists, oral historians, designers, programmers, poets,

O'Driscoll:
  musicians, cultural activists, and performers to learn about,

O'Driscoll:
  share, and study literary sound recordings. We

O'Driscoll:
  are committed to the development, preservation, accessibility, and study

O'Driscoll:
  of literary audio. And to that end our researchers and students are building

O'Driscoll:
  a national network of literary audio, recovering and digitizing

O'Driscoll:
  thousands of literary performances from the magnetic tape era, that

O'Driscoll:
  is reel-to-reel and cassette tape recordings that together comprise a vast

O'Driscoll:
  and important cultural heritage. But we're also

O'Driscoll:
  very much engaged in the current moment of creation and to that end we support

O'Driscoll:
  and celebrate literary performances such as this, recording and

O'Driscoll:
  preserving them for posterity. SpokenWeb's Archive of the

O'Driscoll:
  Present, developed by our project center at Concordia University,

O'Driscoll:
  Montreal, preserves digital sound recordings, video,

O'Driscoll:
  and print materials that document SpokenWeb events produced across
